House adjourned at 11.00 p.m. The following answers to questions were circulated: Centrelink Offices: Queensland (Question No. 1433) Mr Bevis asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 12 April 2000: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 1071 (Hansard, 17 February 2000, page 13751), did the 16 redundancies at the Wynnum office occur at the same time. (2) What distinction is made between the 7 bona fide and 9 non-bona fide redundancies. (3) Who made the decision to offer either bona fide or non-bona fide redundancies. (4) On what basis were the 9 employees offered the non-bona fide redundancy. (5) Has the Wynnum office recruited new staff since May 1999; if so, have any of those new staff been employed to perform the same duties as those 9 non-bona fide redundant employees. (6) Was a decision made to make the 9 non-bona fide employees bona fide redundancies. (7) Was any ruling or advice sought from the Australian Taxation Office in relation to the manner in which the 9 non-bona fide redundancies were to be treated; if so, what was that ruling/advice. (8) When were the 9 non-bona fide redundancy employees advised that their redundancies would be treated as non-bona fide. following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) No. The voluntary redundancies took place over the period May 1998 to July 1999. (2) Redundancies in Centrelink are determined in accordance with the 1999-2002 Centrelink Development Agreement (page 88). Fourteen of the 16 were offered voluntary redundancies in accordance with the criteria: “The services of the employee cannot be effectively used because of technological or other changes in the work methods of Centrelink or changes in the nature, extent or organisation of the functions of Centrelink” (point 2, section 36). This criteria defines a ‘non-bona fide’ redundancy. A bona fide redundancy is where the officer’s position is excess to requirements or the officer’s position has been moved to another locality and the officer is unwilling to move. In the case of the Wynnum CSC, only two of the 16 redundancies met the latter criteria. The remainder were offered as non-bona fide redundancies. In preparing this further advice, investigations at the area level have indicated that there was an error in the original breakdown in the classification of bona and non-bona fide redundancies at Wynnum as advised in my response to question no 1071. However, all staff were provided with a correct written estimate of their final payments, including taxation liability, prior to their accepting the redundancy. (3) The Area Manager, Brisbane. (4) See answer to question 2. (5) Yes. In the period from 1 January 1998, 22 staff have been recruited to the Wynnum/Capalaba CSC, seven of these since May 1999. These staff are performing the work of those staff who accepted non-bona fide redundancies as well as of other staff who exited Centrelink during this period for other reasons. (6) It was the intention that the 14 redundancies offered to officers be non-bona fide redundancies and no decision was made to change them. (7) Advice was sought from the Australian Taxation Office which in part stated “In the situation covered by paragraph (b), the job is still there and the employee will be replaced by another employee to do the work. The situation therefore does not meet the criteria to qualify as a bona fide redundancy”. (8) All CSO’s were advised by the CSC Manager or Assistant Manager that the basis of the redundancy offer was paragraph (b) ‘not adapting well to change’ and therefore non-bona fide. In all cases these discussions took place before the officers accepted redundancy offers.
title: Atsic So He Is Confident That He Is Right Australians Are Simply Not Finding Their Way

speaker: Mr Anthony
theText: The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided theMandatory Sentencing: International Convention Compliance (Question No. 1484) (1) Have representatives of his Department been requested to advise the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade in respect to matters relating to mandatory sentencing and, in particular, Australia’s compliance with international conventions in respect to that matter; if so, when was it arranged for those representatives to brief the committee. (2) Has the briefing been cancelled or postponed; if so, why. (1) I am advised that the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade requested representatives of my Department to brief the Committee on mandatory sentencing on 13 April 2000. (2) I am advised that the Department was told on that day that the briefing was cancelled. The reason for the cancellation would have to be sought from the Committee. Petrol Prices: Competition (Question No. 1487) Mr Andren asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 May 2000: (1) In response to my question without notice (Hansard, 12 April 2000, page 15119) regarding transparency in wholesale petrol pricing, did he say that when the recommendation of the ACCC was put to the Australian Senate to deregulate the petroleum industry at the retail level, it was opposed by a political party which was more interested in keeping up differential rates for rural and regional people than in acting on that recommendation and bringing the differential down; if so, was the legislation to which he referred the Petroleum Retail Legislation Repeal Bill 1998. (2) If so, (a) did that legislation pass the House of Representatives on 11 March 1999, (b) was it introduced to the Senate on 22 March 1999 and (c) does it remain on the Senate Notice Paper under Government Business, undebated and not voted on; if so, does he stand by his statement in response to my question; if not, (d) to which legislation was he referring and (e) how was it opposed by the Senate. (1) Hansard (12 April 2000, page 15119) contains an accurate record of my response to your question without notice. The legislation to which I was referring was the Petroleum Retail Legislation Repeal Bill 1998. (2) (a) Yes. (b) Yes. (c) Yes: Following the return from the 1999 winter recess, the Government held extensive negotiations with the non-Government parties in the Senate on its reform package and associated Repeal Bill. The non-Government parties would not agree to the passage of the Repeal Bill at that time. At the same time the Government sought to implement part of the reform package through a temporary increase in BP’s quota under the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act by way of the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Amendment Regulations 1999 (No.2). In September 1999 Labor and the Democrats combined to disallow these Regulations, making reference to their desire to retain the Sites Act for at least another two years. As a result of the non-Government parties’ decision to oppose the reform package and associated Repeal Bill and their vote to disallow regulations associated with the deregulation of the petroleum industry at the retail level, the Government has decided not to proceed with the Repeal Bill until the major participants in the industry agree on the petroleum reform package. Goods and Services Tax: Mobile and Manufactured Home Sales (Question No. 1488) Mr Horne asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 May 2000:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Mcclelland Asked The Attorney
theText: General, upon notice, on 9 May 2000:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Williams
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:On selling their homes, will the owners of mobile homes or manufactured homes be treated in the same way as other home owners in that the price of their home will be GST free. The sale of a mobile home or a manufactured home used for residential accommodation will not be subject to GST if it is sold by an individual who is not engaged in the enterprise of selling mobile homes or manufactured homes. This is how the majority of used mobile homes and established manufactured homes are expected to be sold. Established manufactured or demountable housing comes within the definition of residential premises and will be input taxed on sale if it is affixed to land. Supplies of demountable buildings that are not residential premises will not be subject to GST unless sold in the course of an enterprise that is carried on. Rivers: Water Flows (Question No. 1495) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 9 May 2000: (1) Has the Minister’s attention been drawn to the Australian Conservation Foundation Report in Habitat Australia 2000 concerning the Snowy River. (2) Have water savings in the Murray-Darling generated by the expenditure of tens of millions of Natural Heritage Trust dollars been used to increase the flow of the Murray-Darling, or have they been used to allow expansion in irrigated agriculture. following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) Yes. (2) Natural Heritage Trust projects with the potential to generate water savings are those funded through the Murray-Darling 2001 Program and the National Landcare Program. These projects aim at improving water use efficiency either on or off-farm. Eligible activities for Trust funding include: . improved on-farm irrigation management practices . installation of more efficient on-farm irrigation systems . refurbishment or upgrading of off-farm water delivery systems . recycling of drainage water . demonstration activities on farms and training and education courses. It is also relevant that any expansion of irrigated agriculture can only take place within the water allocations available under the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council ‘Cap’ on diversions. Most Natural Heritage Trust projects submitted for funding by the Basin community have been dominated by issues of water quality; control of water-tables to manage salinity and associated downstream impacts; riverine corridor restoration and protection; and improved aquatic habitat. The Murray-Darling 2001 Program has recently developed a new Irrigation and Water Use Efficiency component, which has as objectives: encouraging adoption of improved irrigation management practices; improving distribution system efficiency and security of water supply to irrigators; improving the management of water reuse systems; and providing additional water for environmental flows. Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport: Runway Operations (Question No. 1504) 10 May 2000: Further to the question No. 1165 (Hansard, 4 April 2000, page 14697), for the 12 month period ending 30 November 1999, what runway modes of operation were used at Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport and for what percentage of time was each mode of operation adopted on weekends.

speaker: Mr Mcclelland Asked The Minister For Transport And Regional Services, Upon Notice, On
theText: Airservices Australia has advised that the runway mode usage distribution on weekends for the 12 month period ending 30 November 1999 was as follows: Mode5 7.19% Mode7 15.94% Mode9 26.48% Mode10 24.57% Mode12 0.07% Mode13 0.39% Mode14a 18.71% Job Network: Intensive Assistance Contracts (Question No. 1522) Mr Tanner asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 10 May 2000: (1) Further to the answer to part (2) of question No 1212 (Hansard, 9 May 2000, page 16103), why was a detailed assessment of the financial impact of handing back Employment National’s (EN) Job Network1 contracts not undertaken before the contracts were handed back. (2) Further to the answer to part (4) of question No 1212, will he provide further supporting information that the cost to EN of servicing the contracts would have been $22 million and what is the detailed breakdown of that figure. (3) Further to the answer to part (4) of question No 1212, was the financial advice tendered by EN provided to him after his decision to direct EN to hand back intensive assistance contracts; if so, why did he not seek advice before issuing that direction. (4) Further to the answer to part (8) of question No 1212, before issuing such a ministerial direction to a Government Business Enterprise (GBE) is it standard practice to seek advice from that GBE on the material effect of such a direction. (5) Did the Minister for Employment Services, the Minister’s advisers or the Minister’s Department, discuss his direction to EN to hand back the contracts with him, his advisers or his Department before that decision was made; if so, did he, his advisers or his Department express a view as to whether the contracts should be handed back; if so, what was that view. (1) An assessment of the financial impact of handing back EN’s Intensive Assistance (Flex 3) Job Network1 contracts was undertaken for EN by its accounting advisers. Based on advice from EN management, that assessment assumed that EN would cease servicing Intensive Assistance clients under Job Network 1, apart from those placed in sustainable employment prior to the commencement of W2, given the large losses associated with the business. (2) EN advises that the costings are based on projections of minimum costs required to continue to service Intensive Assistance clients. The costs included a reducing profile of staff required to service ongoing Intensive Assistance clients, property, IT and telephony costs for those staff, (including appropriate adjustments to systems, and maintaining sites that would otherwise have closed) and candidate 1 extra’ expenditure. The costing assumptions did not include consideration of staff retention payments for staff with short term futures in the company.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Sodprops And Other Over The Water 6 65

speaker: Mr Fahey
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Department of Family and Community Services: Commonwealth Funded Programs, Tasmania (Question No. 1534) Ms O’Byrne asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 11 May 2000: (1) Does the Minister’s Department administer any Commonwealth funded programs for which community organisations, businesses or individuals can apply for funding in Tasmania; if so, what are the programs. (2) Does the Minister’s Department advertise these funding opportunities; if so, (a) what print media outlets have been used for the advertising of each of these programs and (b) were these paid advertisements. following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) The Department of Family and Community Services administers funded programs for which community organisations, businesses or individual can apply for funding in Tasmania. The programs administered by the Department are; the Emergency Relief Program, the Partnerships against Domestic Violence Program, the Family and Community networks Initiative, the Youth Activity Service Program, the Family Relationships Program, the Good Beginnings National Parenting Project, the Disability Services Program and the Family and Children’s Services Program. (2) (a) Where new or uncommitted funding is available and if it is apparent that there is more than one possible organisation to deliver a program the funding is advertised. Within the current financial year, in Tasmania, programs have been advertised in “The Mercury”, “The Examiner”, “The Advocate”, “Tasmanian Country”, “Australian Retiree”, “The Derwent Valley Gazette”, “The Deloraine Community News”, “The Northern Midlands Community News” and “The Tasmanian Business Reporter”. (b) This advertising was paid. Job Network: Outcomes (Question No. 1556) Ms Kernot asked the Minister for Employment Services, upon notice, on 11 May 2000: (1) How many of the intensive assistance initial outcomes for which a provider has received a payment under the Job Network to date are (a) training outcomes and (b) paid work. (2) How many of the intensive assistance 13 week outcomes for which a provider h received a payment under the Job Network to date are (a) training outcomes and (b) paid work. (3) What portion of the total does the training outcome represent. (4) What percentage of sum spent under the Job Network is on accredited training. (5) What was the total sum spent on accredited training in the last 12 months. (6) How many long term unemployed were placed into employment in the first 19 months of the Job Network. (7) How many long term unemployed were scheduled to be placed into employment in the first 19 months of the Job Network. (8) How many job seekers were placed into employment in the first 19 months of the Job Network. (9) How many job seekers were scheduled to be placed into employment in the first 19 months of the Job Network. (10) How many job seekers in total have been placed in work in the last 12 months. (11) How many intensive assistance clients have been placed in work in the last 12 months. (12) How many non intensive assistance job seekers have been placed in work in the last 12 months.
title: Sodprops And Other Over The Water 6 65

speaker: Mr Anthony
theText: The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the(13) How many providers missed out on contracts under Job Network2 because their bids faded to comply with the revised GST guidelines. (14) How many Job Network sites are located within 50 metres of each other. (15) What are the-locations of these Job Network sites. (16) Counting, Job Network sites located within 50 metres of each other as one site, what is the number of sites under Job Network 2. (1) (a) nil see (2) (b) nil see (2) (2) (a) An Intensive Assistance outcomes payment is made when a job seeker who has been placed in a job or an education/training course remains in the course for a semester or continues to receive income sufficient to result in a M or partial reduction in income support payments over a period of 13 consecutive weeks. These 13 week outcomes are referred to as interim outcomes. From1 May 1998 to 19 May 2000, a total of 4648 interim outcomes payments were made for the placement of job seekers into education or training. (b) From1 May 1998 to 19 May 2000, a total of 68 287 interim outcomes payments were made for the placement of job seekers into employment. The placement into a job which "4anchors" such a 13 week outcome may be eligible for a payment under Job Matching arrangements. (3) Education and training placements are 6.4 percent of interim outcomes. (4) and (5) Accredited training is not a separate service within Job Network. Job Network members are not required to account for expenditure on various forms of assistance to clients. The department cannot, therefore, report on expenditure on accredited training within Job Network. (6) In the first 19 months of Job Network operation around 165 000 Job Matching placements were for long term unemployed job seekers. (7) There was no target for the placement of long term unemployed job seekers in the first 19 months of Job Network. (8) Around 440 000 eligible Job Matching placements (potentially attracting, a Job Matching fee) were achieved in the first 19 months of Job Network operation. (9) There was no target for the placement of job seekers in the first 19 months of Job Network. (10) Approximately 293 000 eligible Job Matching placements were achieved in the 12 months to end April 2000. (11) Around 90 000 eligible Job Matching placements were made for Intensive Assistance participants in the 12 months to end April. 2000. (12) In the 12 months to end April 2000 around 203 000 eligible Job Matching placements were for job seekers who were not participating in Intensive Assistance. (13) Twenty-nine organisations were not considered for contracts to deliver Intensive Assistance services for the sole reason that they submitted prices all of which were below the minimum price specified in the GST related addendum to the Request for Tender. (14), (15) and (16) As at 23 May 2000, there were 2054 Job Network sites. The department records the addresses of sites; it does not measure the distance between sites. Dairy Industry Deregulation Community Assistance Package: Tasmanian Allocation (Question No. 1557) Ms O’Byrne asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 29 May 2000: (1) What proportion of the Dairy Industry Deregulation Community Assistance Package will be allocated to Tasmania. (2) What process is in place for the application for funding under this program. (3) What process is in place for the assessment of applications.
title: Sodprops And Other Over The Water 6 65

speaker: Mr Abbott
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Sodprops And Other Over The Water 6 65

speaker: Mr Truss
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(1) The Dairy Regional Assistance Program (Dairy RAP) is but one component of the Dairy Structural Adjustment Package. Under Dairy RAP, there is no specific allocation on a state by state basis. Funding allocations will therefore be assessed nationally in the light of the numbers and types of funding requests received, the information provided by the proponents in their applications and the advice from their respective Area Consultative Committee(s). (2) Procedures for application and funding for the program are currently being developed between my department and the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. I understand that applications for the Dairy Regional Assistance Programme will take essentially the same form as those under the existing Regional Assistance Program, administered by the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. (3) The Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business is developing, in consultation with my department, a process for consideration of applications. Initial applications will need to be lodged through Area Consultative Committees. Area Consultative Committees, which work in partnership with government, business and the community will put forward for consideration applications which demonstrate the capacity to create sustainable regional employment opportunities and/or services that lead to ongoing regional benefits. Centrelink: Contracts with IBM (Question No. 1566) Mr Tanner asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 29 May 2000: (1) Since1 July 1999, what contracts have been signed between Centrelink and IBM. (2) What products and services were included in those contracts. (3) Which of those products and services are within the scope of Centrelink outsourcing as per the tender request. (4) Were these contracts approved by the Office of Asset Sales and IT Outsourcing (OASITO) before Centrelink’s commitment. (5) Was OASITO involved in the negotiation of the contracts. (6) Who signed the contracts on behalf of Centrelink and the Commonwealth. following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) Four agreements have been signed since 1 July 1999. These are: . Deed Number IBM/DSS/FEP1. The effective date of this deed was 5 August 1999 and is an amendment to upgrade hardware and extend the term of the then existing deed to 31 December 2000. . Deed Number IBM/DSS/MF1. The effective date of this amendment was 26 December 1999. This amendment extended the hardware lease term to 31 December 2002, incorporated the then current monthly leased software and provided additional processors, software, services and maintenance. . Deed Number IBM/DSS/MF1. The effective date of this amendment was 12 March 2000. This amendment upgraded certain items of hardware. . Agreement dated 30 September 1999 for extraction and transformation tools. (2) Deed Number IBM/DSS/FEP1 Included in this Deed was mainframe hardware and Vendor Support Services for an estimated two days. It also provided for IBM to assist Centrelink in the implementation, planning and migration of the hardware. IBM/DSS/MF1 Effective date 26 December 1999 Included in this Deed was network software, mainframe software and hardware. Also included under this contract amendment was the renewal of annual maintenance charges (software subscription renewals) for existing products.

Approval for contracts was not sought as this is not a requirement. (5) OASITO was not involved in the negotiation of the contracts. (6) The National Manager, Information and Technology Infrastructure Services, signed all four agreements on behalf of Centrelink and the Commonwealth. Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation: Research Facilities Closure (Question No. 1570) Mrs Crosio asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, upon notice, on 29 May 2000: (1) Does the Minister support the closure of the CSIRO research facility at Prospect. (2) When did the Minister first become aware of a report into the CSIRO’s Livestock Research Infrastructure. (3) When did the Minister first become aware of proposals to close the CSIRO research facility at Prospect. (4) Have there been discussions between the Minister’s Department and Boral Quarries at Prospect; if so, what was the (a) date and (h) nature of the discussions. (5) Have arrangements been made in regard to the future use of the site by Boral Quarries or any other company. (6) What plans have been made for the future usage of the site. (7) Was there a $12 million upgrade of the CSIRO Prospect facility in 1995; if so, what specific areas of the site were upgraded and what was the individual cost of each area upgraded. (8) What sum of Commonwealth funding was allocated to the CSIRO research facility at Prospect in (a) 1990-91, (b) 1991-92, (c) 1992-93, (d) 1993-94, (e) 1994-95, (f) 1995-96, (g) 1996-97, (h) 199798, (i) 1998-99 and (j) 1999-2000. (9) Did the Minister receive advice detailing the closure of the CSIRO’s research facility at Prospect; if so, (a) on what date was the advice received and (b) did the advice state that the closure of the facility would (i) involve the loss of highly skilled research staff currently stationed at Prospect and result in the closure of the several research programs owing to the loss of key scientific expertise, (ii) at the least, incur months of disruption to research programs of national importance to the $7 billion Livestock Industry that would affect producers across Australia and (iii) cut established links between the CSIRO’s Prospect facility and the animal nutrition, pig and dairy industries in the Greater Sydney region. (10) What sum of Commonwealth money has been appropriated to allow for relocation for staff and equipment, recruitment of new staff and redundancy packages for staff from the Prospect site. answer to the honourable member’s questions: (1) CSIRO’s decision to close the Prospect facility flows from recommendations by a committee of senior industry representatives in a Review of Livestock Research Infrastructure commissioned in
title: Sodprops And Other Over The Water 6 65

speaker: Mr Moore
theText: The Minister for Industry, Science and Resources has provided the followingDecember 1999 by the Organisation’s Chief Executive. CSIRO’s response to this report is a matter for CSIRO. (2) CSIRO advised the Minister about the deliberations of the Review of Livestock Research Infrastructure on 14 April 2000. (3) On 14 April 2000, CSIRO advised the Minister that the Review Team was considering recommending that CSIRO’s research facility at Prospect be closed. CSIRO’s decision to accept the Review recommendation that the Prospect research facility be closed was communicated to the Minister on 15 May 2000. (4)(a)(b) In 1998/99 Boral initiated a State Environment Planning Policy 59 proposal for redevelopment of its site for employment and residential uses. In 1998 CSIRO lodged a proposal with Holroyd Council for the rezoning of 18 hectares of the Prospect site which was surplus to requirements. This area, about one third of the total site area, has been designated for disposal once rezoning is approved. The Boral site is adjacent to CSIRO’s Prospect site and, as two adjoining owners with concurrent planning proposals, CSIRO and Boral were required to reach agreement on joint access and services to the development areas. CSIRO had a number of discussions with Boral in late 1999 and early 2000 on a possible Boral lease of a building in CSIRO’s Prospect site (Building 35). This lease did not proceed. (5) No. CSIRO does not have any arrangements or agreements with Boral or any other company about the future use of CSIRO’s Prospect site. (6) Other than the disposal of the 18 hectares of land surplus to requirements (see response to Q 4) CSIRO has not made any plans for the future use of the balance of the Prospect site. A property strategy is being developed by CSIRO and its equity partner, the Woolmark Company, on the future use of the balance of the site. (7) A total of $9.2 million was expended in 1994/95 on facilities at Prospect comprising: a new facility for the McMaster Laboratory at a cost of $4.5 million refurbishment of certain existing facilities including the library, theatrette, climate control building, post mortem facility and animal house at a total cost of $4.7 million. (8) Funding has not been specifically allocated to the Prospect site. In CSIRO funds are allocated to programs and not sites. CSIRO Animal Production has had staff located at up to nine different sites over the last decade and some programs are carried out on several of these sites. Commonwealth funding allocated to CSIRO’s Division of Animal Production as a whole, is: (a) 1990-91$11.5 million (b) 1991-92$12.6 million (c) 1992-93$15.8 million (d) 1993-94$14.2 million (e) 1994-95$13.8 million (f) 1995-96$17.8 million (g) 1996-97$16.6 million (h) 1997-98$15.6 million (i) 1998-99$14.8 million (j) 1999-2000$15.5 million (9) (a) CSIRO advised the Minister in writing on 15 May 2000 of its decision to accept the Review Committee’s recommendation that the Prospect site be closed. (b) (i) CSIRO advised the Minister that all staff at Prospect would be offered relocation with their jobs to other CSIRO sites and that it aims to maximise the number of staff that transfer to other locations by taking all practical measures to provide attractive relocation packages and minimise the stress of relocation. CSIRO also advised that, despite this, some staff might be unable to relocate and will instead opt for redundancy. (ii) Advice from CSIRO noted the possibility of short to medium term disruption to some research groups, possibly including the loss of work areas to CSIRO. (iii) An Implementation Team has been commissioned by CSIRO to ensure the orderly withdrawal from the Prospect site and to ensure the most appropriate relocation destinations for research groups into order to maintain and extend their industry links. (10) No additional Commonwealth money has been appropriated for this purpose. South Pacific Regional Trade and Economic Cooperation Agreement: Garments from Fiji (Question No. 1574) Mr Gibbons asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, upon notice, on 29 May 2000: (1) Will proposed changes to the South Pacific regional trade and economic cooperation agreement allow garments made in Fiji from non-Australian woven fabric to be provided duty free into Australia. (2) Does this have the potential to adversely affect Australian manufacturers in the wool weaving and conversion industries. (3) What action will the Minister take to ensure manufacturers like ADA in Bendigo are not disadvantaged by the changes. answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) The proposed new arrangements provide for preferential access for TCF goods produced in Forum Island Countries (including Fiji), and incorporates a change in the method for utilising local area content for TCF goods. The local area content of a product is the input from Australia, New Zealand or Forum Island Countries. This new approach broadens the range of products able to be produced economically in a Forum Island Country. (2) The Minister’s intention is that the proposed new scheme will not disadvantage Australian textile producers and he has instructed his Department accordingly. The Department of Industry, Science and Resources has had extensive and ongoing consultation with industry to discuss the nature of the scheme. (3) Representatives of ADA in Bendigo have been involved in the consultation process and their concerns will be taken into account in the finalisation of the new scheme. Visas: Visitors (Question No. 1584) Mr Sciacca asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 30 May 2000: (1) What are the official figures for the total number of visitor visa applications received and the number of applications refused during each year since 1994-95 by departmental posts in (a) Albania, (b) Bangladesh, (c) Bosnia, (d) Bulgaria, (e) Burma, (f) Cambodia, (g) Chile, (h) China, (i) Colombia, (j) Croatia, (k) Czech Republic, (l) Ecuador, (m) El Salvador, (n) Ethiopia, (o) Egypt, (p) Fiji, (q) Greece, (r) Hungary, (s) India, (t) Iran, (u) Iraq, (v) Israel, (w) Jordan, (x) Laos, (y) Lebanon, (z) Lithuania, (aa) FYR Macedonia, (ab) Nepal, (ac) Pakistan, (ad) Peru, (ae) The Philippines, (af) Poland, (ag) Romania, (ah) Russia, (ai) Sri Lanka, (aj) Syria, (ak) Tonga, (al) Turkey, (am) The Ukraine, (an) Uruguay, (ao) Vietnam, (ap) Western Samoa and (aq) Yugoslavia. (2) For each post referred to in part (1), how many visa applications were (a) received and (b) rejected from applicants aged (i) between 20 and 30 years of age, (ii) between 30 and 40 years of age, (iii) between 40 and 50 years of age, (iv) between 50 and 60 years of age and (v) 60 years of age and over.
title: Sodprops And Other Over The Water 6 65

speaker: Mr Moore
theText: The Minister for Industry, Science and Resources has provided the following(3) What are the official figures for the total number of visitor visa applications received and the number of applications refused during each year since 1994-95 by departmental posts in (a) United States and (b) United Kingdom. (4) For each post referred to in part (3), how many visa applications were (a) received and (b) rejected from applicants aged (i) between 20 and 30 years of age, (ii) between 30 and 40 years of age, (iii) between 40 and 50 years of age, (iv) between 50 and 60 years of age and (v) 60 years of age and over. (5) For each post referred to in parts (1) and (3), how many applications for visitor visas in each age group were refused on the grounds that the applicant fitted into one of the categories on the High Risk Factor List. (1) The honourable member will know that the Australian Government does not have posts in all of the countries listed in his question. However, all the data available at this time is included in TableA below. Until November 1998 the Department could only report on refusals by Post, and this was not always indicative of citizenship. From that time the Department has been able to report on refusals by citizenship and accordingly I have also included data, at TableB below, on applications and refusals by citizenship for calendar years 1999 and 2000 (to 31 May). (2) Data on the age and sex of visitor visa applicants is not readily available for reporting purposes at present however systems development work is currently underway to enable data to be easily extracted and reported upon. I have asked officers of my Department to continue to advance this work and provide these statistics to the honourable member when they become available. Given the current position of the systems development, it is not possible to estimate when this information might be available. (3) The honourable member will be aware of the difficulty in making comparisons between the countries discussed in question 1 and the USA and UK. US and UK citizens are eligible, along with the nationals of 31 low risk countries worldwide, to be granted an Electronic Travel Authority (ETA) if they are not listed on the Movement Alert List. Visitor visas, including ETAs, granted to UK and USA nationals during the period requested are included in TablesA and B. (4) See (2) above. (5) Public Interest Criterion 4011 (the “risk factor”) requires any visitor visa applicant who falls within certain age and sex cohorts to demonstrate to the decision-maker that “there is very little likelihood that the applicant will remain after the expiry of any period during which the applicant might be authorised to remain after entry.” While I can state the number of visa applications rejected, the department does not record the reasons for those rejections in a way that can be accessed by the Department’s reporting systems. I can, however, state that the risk factor list is not used to automatically exclude applicants. It operates simply as an “alert” to decision-makers of the potential for continued stay in Australia and requires the applicant to provide a higher level of evidence to support their claim that they are only intending to visit Australia. An applicant will be rejected where they fail to satisfy a decision-maker that a genuine visit is intended. Foreign Aid: Possible Fraud (Question No. 1586) Mr Danby asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 31 May 2000: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a report in the Vietnamese newspaper Lao Dong in November 1999, which alleged fraud by a Vietnamese Government official of $16 000 in Australian aid to the Vietnamese Education Department’s Industry and Education Centre for the production of an ecology text book. (2) Has he made representations to the Vietnamese Government regarding the alleged fraud; if so, what. (3) Has the $16 000 been recovered; if not, what is the status of the investigation. (1) Yes, I am aware that on 22 November 1999 an article appeared in the Lao Dong newspaper in which two allegations of mis-use of DAP funding were made against an individual in the National Centre for Education Technology (NCET). In 1994, the Australian Embassy in Hanoi allocated US$10 000 (AU$13 937) for an Environment Education in Primary Schools project to the NCET. The funds were to develop an environmental education curriculum for primary schools. The Embassy received a receipt from NCET on 12 May 1994 for US$10 000. (2) I have no information to either support or refute allegations of misappropriation of these DAP funds and representations would be inappropriate. (3) The Embassy was advised in January 2000 that the NCET was undertaking an investigation into these allegations. No further information has been advised by the Vietnamese authorities on the state of the investigation. Virgin Blue Airlines Pty Ltd: Services (Question No. 1591) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 1 June 2000: From discussions with Virgin Blue Airlines Pty Ltd, what is the airline’s intentions (a) for extension of its services beyond the Melbourne. Sydney and Brisbane triangle to less profitable regional routes and (b) with respect to the servicing and maintenance of its fleet within Australia by staff directly employed by the company.
title: Sodprops And Other Over The Water 6 65

speaker: Mr Downer
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Total 2 646 3 37 417 2 940 981 43 733 3 155 3 65 198 3 076 0 84 812 3 088 1 77 278 2 860 431 67 470 Offsh 20 68 17 93

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(a) Virgin Blue has publicly announced that phase one of its Australian operations will focus on the Melbourne/Sydney/Brisbane triangle. If Virgin is successful in the start up phase, it has expressed the intention to consider expanding services to other points in Australia, including regional points, in phases two and three in around 18 months time. (b) Virgin Blue has made a commercial decision to outsource its aircraft maintenance functions rather than directly employing aircraft maintenance staff. I understand that Virgin Blue recently announced it had contracted Jet Care Pty Ltd to carry out aircraft maintenance in Brisbane. Jet care is a Queensland based company and is a wholly owned subsidiary of Flight West Airlines. (Question No. 1607) Mr Latham asked the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on Tuesday, 6 June 2000. (1) Did the Australian National Training Authority Ministerial Council consider the 1989 (2) Has Australia consulted any members of the South Pacific Forum on ratification or accession since the answer to question No. 890 (Hansard, 11 October 1999, page 11293). (1) No. (2) No. Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry: Meeting (Question No. 1613) Mr Danby asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 6 June 2000: (1) Did he meet his Iranian counterpart, Iran’s Construction Jihad Minister, Mohammad Saeedicki in Sydney on 30 May 2000. (2) Is he able to say whether the expression ‘Jihad’ means Holy War. (3) What was the purpose of his meeting with the Construction Jihad Minister. (4) Was he invited by the Construction Jihad Minister to visit Teheran and did he accept the invitation. (5) Did he raise Australia’s concerns about human rights with the Construction Jihad Minister; if not, will he be raising these human rights issues should he visit Teheran. (1) I did not meet with Mohammad Saeedicki on 30 May 2000 in Sydney. However, I did meet with the Minister for Construction Jihad, Mr Saidi Kia and his delegation during his visit to Canberra on 29 May 2000. (2) I am advised that the direct translation of ‘Jihad’ in the Iranian language (Farsi) is ‘crusade’. (3) Minister Kia’s portfolio is responsible for key areas of agriculture including livestock and dairy, natural resource management, fisheries and aquaculture, as well as forestry. At the meeting I had with Minister Kia we discussed opportunities relevant to my portfolio’s export interests. (4) Minister Kia informally invited me to visit Iran during the meeting. I indicated that I was interested in visiting the Middle East at some time in the future. No official invitation from the Iranian Government has been received. (5) No.

speaker: Mr Truss
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question’s are as follows:Immigration Detention Centres: Detainees (Question No. 1614) Dr Theophanous asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 6 June 2000: (1) How many persons were held in immigration detention centres throughout Australia on 6 June 2000. (2) How many persons were held in each centre. (3) How many persons have been in detention for more than (a) 9 months and (b) 18 months. (4) How many persons in detention centres have applications before the (a) Federal Court and (b) Refugee Tribunal. (5) How many persons in detention centres are eligible for (a) permanent residence and (b) a three year temporary refugee visa. (1) There were 3601 persons in immigration detention centres throughout Australia on 6 June 2000. (2) On6 June 2000, immigration detention centres had the following populations :RRPHUD  &XUWLQ  3RUW+HGODQG  Villawood  0DULE\UQRQJ  3HUWK  (3) (a) On 13 June 2000 there were 464 persons who were in detention for more than 9 months. (b) On 13 June 2000 there were 182 persons who were in detention for more than 18 months. (4) (a) Departmental systems are temporarily unable to provide details of how many persons in detention centres have applications before the Federal Court. The Department is currently modifying its Integrated Client Service System. It is planned that this information will be available by early July 2000. (b) On 15 June 2000, there were 89 persons in immigration detention who had applications before the Refugee Review Tribunal. (5) On6 June 2000 there were 670 people in detention who were protection visa applicants and, if found to be in need of protection, eligible for grant of a Permanent Protection Visa providing they met all other applicable visa criteria. There were a further 2860 protection visa applicants in detention who, if found to be in need of protection, were eligible for grant of a Temporary Protection Visa providing they met all other applicable visa criteria. Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs: Staff Relocation (Question No. 1639) Mr Wilkie asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 19 June 2000: (1) Have staff of his Department located in the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) building in Northbridge, WA, been advised that they are to vacate the premises by May 2002. (2) What impact will this have on the operation of his Department in Perth. (3) How many staff members are currently located in the Northbridge office. (4) What functions do they perform. (5) Is his Department moving staff from its premises in the ATO building in Northbridge. (6) To where will staff be moving. (7) What will be the cost of the move.
title: Unesco Convention On Technical And Vocational Education At Its Meeting On 12 November 1999

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(8) What will be the costs of any new furnishings and ancillaries. (1) Informal advice has been provided to my Department by ATO that the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs staff will need to vacate the premises on the expiry of the sublease in May 2002. (2) Relocation would be organised to minimise disruption to clients. (3) 185 staff. (4) The Perth Office’s functions include the full range of services provided by a State/Regional office. This includes client services, citizenship processing, visa processing, compliance activities, settlement activities and a range of corporate functions to support office activities. (5) My Department is not currently moving staff from its premises, but it would need to do so prior to lease expiry in May 2002. (6) No premises have been selected at this point in time. (7) Removal costs are estimated to be $60,000. (8) The costs of furnishings and ancillaries in new premises are estimated to be around $2m.
